notes: This restaurant is pretty unassuming, in a random strip mall in the valley. When we got there, the only woman running it took our order and appeared to just go in the back and cook it herself. And it was delicious. Afterwards she was telling us about her son and how he's a realtor (?) gave us his card.

This is still our #1 restaurant from this series. It's an Argentine deli/market that's got black and white tiled floors, a butcher counter with probably the finest meats in LA, football on the TVs, and servers who kept thinking we speak Spanish. We started with bread and chimichurri and finished with glasses of Merlot, and had an amazing cut of steak in between. Why is it our favorite? I don't think you can beat really good steak.

We went here thinking it was Albanian food, but it turned out to be Armenian AND a rec from an Armenian lady I bought some Salvatore Ferragamo shoes from at the Silverlake Flea. I'm not gonna lie, she seemed nice enough but those shoes gave me blisters for days. Anyways, the food was great and we especially loved the mantee.

This was the only Austrian restaurant in LA, and it happened to be a pretty upscale spot where only like two things on the menu were *truly* Austrian. I won't ever complain about schnitzel and sausage, tbh. And the radler was great. However, the star of the show was the chicken liver pates we had as a little amouse bouche, even though they aren't really Austrian.

So my family is Bengali. Not Bangladeshi, but we do have a lot of food overlap. So naturally I had really high expectations for food from Little Bangladesh. This spot doubled as a market and a restaurant, and it was all a buffet style except for the fresh parathas they would make you upon request. I think I had just gotten back from India a few weeks before we went, so I was freshly fluent in Bengali and got to show off a bit (I definitely sounded like an idiot). We tried quite a few things that I liked to eat growing up, but none were honestly as good as what my mom and grandmas would make.

Bridgetown is a pretty popular spot in LA, so this was a bit different than the usual hole-in-the-wall joints we end up going to. The dishes were a little more spruced up, but I actually loved the fast-casual modern take on Barbadian food. The pigeon peas and rice were really great.

When we saw this spot was in Inglewood, we were like 'when are we gonna make it out there?' But turns out there was a Clippers vs. Knicks game one night that ended up being the perfect excuse. I think this spot made me realize how cool of an experience this series is. I wasn't planning on going to Belize anytime soon, but getting to try the really unique street foods from this country in the comfort of our own city is a really fascinating feeling.

Cepavi is DELICIOUS. I know it's just bread and meat, but everything tasted so good. Aroma Cafe also doubles as a restaurant and a market, service here was really good, and the place was just super comfortable.

We went to one of the Bossa Novas downtown since we were catching a show at The Belasco. In order to try something different, we got the feijoada which came with a million side dishes. All of it was so good but we were so stuffed.

This one was also another stop before a concert at Zebulon. It's in a super unassuming area, and had a Chilean bakery attached to it. Now Chile, I know your food is not globally known as the best, but I actually found the Pastel de choclo quite comforting.

Somehow we always manage on over ordering, even with three people. Shoutout to Shridhar for joining this one. The cheese with the arepa was unlike anything I've had before, just super light and soft. I expected the Bandeja paisa to be good--it's Anthony's favorite thing to get here--but the tamal kinda blew me away. And it was also MASSIVE.

dishes: Cascos de guayaba con queso crema
notes: Nat and Ben joined us for this one. All of it was destroyed between the four of us, and the ropa vieja was the star. I think this was also my first Cubano, which is somewhere at the top of my list of best sandwiches of all time now. As for dessert, the guava with cream cheese was amazing, and reminded me of this one guava and cheese pastry I had at Demo in Lima.
